channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [PDFBOX-5286] Runtime degredation in RC1 and alpha2
item.description:
working/reviewing PDFBOX-5068 and PDFBOX-5263 I've experiencing runtime issues for both 3.0.0-RC1 and 3.0.0-alpha2 when loading and saving a large PDF

https://crossasia-books.ub.uni-heidelberg.de/xasia/reader/download/506/506-42-86246-2-10-20190822.pdf

version runtime in millis
2.0.24 2076
3.0.0-RC1 219472
3.0.0-alpha2 282284

Basic test:

long start = System.currentTimeMillis();
PDDocument pdf = Loader.loadPDF(new File("506-42-86246-2-10-20190822.pdf"));
pdf.save(new NullOutputStream());
pdf.close();        
long end = System.currentTimeMillis();      
System.out.println("Elapsed Time in milliseconds: "+ (end-start));

with NullOuputStream

package org.apache.pdfbox;

import java.io.IOException;
import java.io.OutputStream;

public class NullOutputStream extends OutputStream {

    @Override
    public void write(byte[] b) throws IOException {
        // don't write anything
    }

    @Override
    public void write(byte[] b, int off, int len) throws IOException {
        // don't write anything
    }

    @Override
    public void write(int b) throws IOException {
        // don't write anything
    }
}

I've also running tests using JMH - they support these numbers. The difference in numbers for RC1/alpha2 are within a regular variation.
item.summary: Runtime degredation in RC1 and alpha2

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: The creation of compressed object streams seems to be one of the reasons for the degradation. On my system the numbers are 252.324ms vs. 47.233ms for the current trunk. AFAIK the current code simply creates new compressed object streams instead of reusing the existing one because PDFBox doesn't know if an object is new or has been changed.

Some quick number

2.0.24
saveMediumFile                    1492,319 ±    144,831  ms/op

3.0.0-alpha2
saveMediumFile                    5760,922 ±    661,071  ms/op
saveNoCompressionMediumFile       3647,965 ±    203,258  ms/op

2.0.24
saveLargeFile                     2636,223 ±    345,987  ms/op

3.0.0-alpha2
saveLargeFile                   247090,290 ± 194051,696  ms/op
saveNoCompressionLargeFile       67161,364 ±  19638,638  ms/op

So looks like for small to medium files the impact is modest for both compressed and uncompressed saving but for large ones the numbers are considerably larger even when saving uncompressed.

Commit 1893926 from lehmi@apache.org in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1893926 ]

PDFBOX-5286: rearrange if clauses to optimize performance

Commit 1893927 from lehmi@apache.org in branch 'pdfbox/branches/2.0'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1893927 ]

PDFBOX-5286: rearrange if clauses to optimize performance
I've found an easy optimization to double the performance, w.r.t. saving uncompressed files using the trunk

Numbers from my side:

before commit

PDFBoxPerformance.saveNoCompressionLargeFile          ss    5  55557,758 ± 9645,445  ms/op
PDFBoxPerformance.saveNoCompressionMediumFile         ss    5   4228,877 ±  807,354  ms/op

after commit

PDFBoxPerformance.saveNoCompressionLargeFile          ss    5  32010,558 ± 2286,229  ms/op
PDFBoxPerformance.saveNoCompressionMediumFile         ss    5   4041,268 ±  717,481  ms/op

Quick note on some variance in the numbers to earlier ones. Although I'm making sure while running the tests I'm not doing other tasks I'm not rebooting my device before running which ideally I should. In addition to have a quick comparison the numbers were done doing a SingleShot test where I really should be doing a larger number of iterations). But the trend is clear which was the intent of the test.

lehmi I've changed from

private final Deque<COSBase> objectsToWrite = new LinkedList<>();

to use ArrayDeque with tests passing

private final Deque<COSBase> objectsToWrite = new ArrayDeque<>();

and get these numbers now

PDFBoxPerformance.saveNoCompressionLargeFile          ss    5  11250,910 ± 1742,927  ms/op
PDFBoxPerformance.saveNoCompressionMediumFile         ss    5   3744,894 ±  497,686  ms/op

Maybe worth trying as it's again an easy replacement. (There are some differences between LinkedList and ArrayDeque which I don't think matter as we were not using the List nature and also don't store null entries AFAIU ....)

Commit 1893955 from Maruan Sahyoun in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1893955 ]

PDFBOX-5286: use ArrayDeque for better performance

Commit 1893956 from Maruan Sahyoun in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1893956 ]

PDFBOX-5286: set initial size of ByteArrayOutputStream
msahyoun sorry for the late response. Yes, there is no need for a LinkedList, we just need one of the Deque features. Replacing LinkedList with ArrayDeque is a good idea

For the particular files a lot of the time is spent in COSStream.createView 66% with Filter.decode at 43% and ByteArrayOutputStream.toByteArray at 23%. Both Filter.decode and ByteArrayOutputStream.toByteArray causing a lot of Arrays.copyOf.

I'm looking at replacing the BOS with a more efficient implementation. There are implementations from Apache Commons and Spring and others which sound promising. Setting the initial size already gave me approx 9% improvement.

Commit 1894451 from lehmi@apache.org in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1894451 ]

PDFBOX-5286: dereference compressed object stream object only once

result:

PDFBoxPerformance.saveNoCompressionLargeFile     ss    5  9458,440 ± 2879,303  ms/op
PDFBoxPerformance.saveNoCompressionMediumFile    ss    5  2880,029 ±  333,981  ms/op

lehmi I further looked into where the time is spent. COSStream.createView takes a lot of it which is if I'm not mistaken because for every object contained in a stream PDFStreamParser creates a new view which is reading the content, uncompresses it again and again. (I was printing the COSStream hash to the console for every createView call and see that indead this should be what happens)

I did a very quick hack and stored the initially parsed uncompressed content byte[] in a COSStream member as a cache and returning that contained in a new RandomAccesReadBuffer  when available instead of rereading/uncompressing.

That brings the numbers further down to 7s for the large file and 1.4s for the medium file.

I didn't look into possible caveats but was only looking for the performance gains so there might be side effects.

WDYT?

Yes, I agree, compressed object streams are one main reason. My last commit fixes an issue with recreating the COSStream itself again and again. If it comes to caching there are always two side of a coin. On one hand it is (hopefully) faster and on the other hand it will consume more memory. Let's start with caching the decompressed stream itself. In the long run we should cache the COS-objects and not the stream to avoid caching the data twice. I'm not sure how to do so, storing those objects within the COSStream, the object pool of COSDocument or by introducing a new class for compressed streams which inherits COSStream.

Commit 1894994 from lehmi@apache.org in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1894994 ]

PDFBOX-5286: read and cache all objects of a compressed object stream instead of parsing it again and again for every single object of the stream

Sorry, for taking so long, my first version produces some strange test failure and it was hard to find the cause. It the end it was easy to fix, but hard to figure out. However, I've changed the COSParser so that all objects of a compressed object stream are read if one of the objects is needed. Those objects are cache within the COSParser until they are dereferenced as well.

result:

Benchmark                                           Mode  Cnt     Score     Error   Units
PDFBoxPerformance.saveNoCompressionMediumFile         ss    5  1389,974 ± 231,578   ms/op
PDFBoxPerformance.saveNoCompressionLargeFile          ss    5  4652,939 ± 1029,527  ms/op
lehmi  Corrected the numbers - the last commit wasn't included in my benchmark - sorry for the mistake

Commit 1895037 from lehmi@apache.org in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1895037 ]

PDFBOX-5286: don't rely on an ordered map as return value based on a proposal by xiedaxia1hao closes #136

Commit 1895038 from lehmi@apache.org in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1895038 ]

PDFBOX-5286: add a test for parseAllObjects

msahyoun Looks like the numbers for the current trunk are similar to those from 2.0.24 at least for the medium large file.

Any idea where to look next? Maybe there are to many seek operations because of to many randomly ordered accesses?
lehmi  will try to analyse the profiler data generated with JMH today.

Commit 1895221 from lehmi@apache.org in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1895221 ]

PDFBOX-5286: avoid to call contains as direct object are never part of the already traversed objects
My last change cuts down the processing time for compression by a factor of 10 for the large file. Unfortunately I've overlooked an issue with another testcase. I'm working an that

Commit 1895223 from lehmi@apache.org in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1895223 ]

PDFBOX-5286: readded check for COSDictionaries to avoid infinite recursion until we find a more efficient way

Commit 1895228 from lehmi@apache.org in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1895228 ]

PDFBOX-5286: avoid to call contains as direct object of a COSArray are never part of the already traversed objects
I've reverted a part of my changes for COSDictionaries which reduces the performance gain to a factor of 5

lehmi again looks better. Not only the runtime number went down but also the error margin.

Benchmark                                    Mode  Cnt     Score     Error  Units
LoadAndSave.saveNoCompressionLargeFile         ss    5  4149,505 ± 370,951  ms/op

Looking at the profiling data java.util.ArrayDeque.contains () still accounts for 1.842 ms That's mainly coming from COSArray within a COSDictionary. I'm currently working on adding the benchmarks as a new module. Will add it as a patch to a new ticket for review before doing a commit so there is a chance to review it before it lands in source control
msahyoun You've posted the results for the case without compression. My last changes targeted the compression case. Did you copy the wrong description or simply misunderstood my commit message?

Benchmark                  Mode  Cnt      Score      Error  Units
LoadAndSave.saveLargeFile    ss    5  23973,671 ± 3521,180  ms/op

That's the number for saving in compressed mode. Although still much higher than 2.0 already much faster than when the issue surfaced. Will take a look at the profiling data.

.

Most of the time is spent in nested calls as can be seen in above chart. Other branches look similar. Haven't looked at the code if the behaviour is expected or not.

msahyoun COSWriter collects all relevant objects by traversing the pdf recursively. To avoid going backwards and most likely running into an infinite loop when a link to a parent object is hit those objects are collected within the Set writtenObjects. Calling contains on that Set is one or maybe the performance issue.

Commit 1898481 from lehmi@apache.org in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1898481 ]

PDFBOX-5286: add all indirect objects, simplify

Commit 1898482 from lehmi@apache.org in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1898482 ]

PDFBOX-5286: simplify

The last commit breaks the TestFax_56972.pdf test case in PDAcroFormFlattenTest. (enable this test case first, and then look at the differences). The result files are in pdfbox/target/test-output/flatten/out .
Interesting, I'm going to have a look

Commit 1898624 from lehmi@apache.org in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1898624 ]

PDFBOX-5286: ensure that the "same" indirect objects are referenced by the same key otherwise they are not the same

The compression code mixed up indirect COSInteger which are the same but are holding the same value. The code which was removed when simplifying repaired that fault but transforming such indirect object into direct objects.

My last commit fixes the root cause within the compression code. But in the end we have to think about how to handle different COSInteger objects holding the same value w.r.t. hashCode and equals. But we should discuss that on dev@
Thanks, the flatten test works.

Commit 1898652 from lehmi@apache.org in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1898652 ]

PDFBOX-5286: optimize the traversing of the object structure when looking for objects to be compressed

I looks like I found a way to speed up the collection of the objects to be compressed.

These are results in my environment using the current trunk

Benchmark                  Mode  Cnt     Score     Error  Units
LoadAndSave.saveLargeFile  avgt   25  6576,536 ± 101,813  ms/op

Benchmark                               Mode  Cnt     Score     Error  Units
LoadAndSave.saveNoCompressionLargeFile  avgt   25  3057,738 ± 120,146  ms/op

Here is the result for the compression case without my recent changes in place

Benchmark                  Mode  Cnt      Score     Error  Units
LoadAndSave.saveLargeFile  avgt   25  19959,258 ± 295,778  ms/op

The compression code is now 3 times faster than before

Commit 1898769 from lehmi@apache.org in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1898769 ]

PDFBOX-5286: optimize if clause to speed up compression

I've found another way to optimize the compression. The benchmark for large files is now as twice as fast as writing without compression 

Benchmark                  Mode  Cnt     Score    Error  Units
LoadAndSave.saveLargeFile  avgt   25  1761,569 ± 51,538  ms/op
lehmi  this is great - more than 10 times faster compared to initial situation.

Commit 1898840 from lehmi@apache.org in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1898840 ]

PDFBOX-5286: refactor direct object cache, drop no longer needed class TraversedCOSElement

When refactoring the cache for the direct objects I've realized that the class TraversedCOSElement is no longer needed so that I've dropped it. I've an idea for another optimization, but I've to check it first
For now we are done here. There is plenty of room for some other refactorings, but IMHO we should handle them in separate tickets.

Commit 1899098 from lehmi@apache.org in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1899098 ]

PDFBOX-5286: sonar fix
